ETYMOLOGY: From Old French hermite, from Latin eremita, from Ancient Greek ἐρημίτης (erēmítēs, 'person of the desert'), from ἔρημος (érēmos, 'desert, solitary').

MEANINGS.POS_TIP: A word (other than a pronoun) used to identify any of a class of people, places, or things (common noun), or to name a particular one of these (proper noun).
MEANINGS.DEF_EN: A person who lives in solitude, often out of religious devotion or for spiritual reasons.
MEANINGS.DEF_ZH: 隐士；遁世者（常因宗教或精神原因而独居）
MEANINGS.SENT_EN: The ancient monk chose to live as a hermit in the mountains, seeking enlightenment.
MEANINGS.SENT_ZH: 那位古老的僧侣选择在山中过隐士生活，以寻求顿悟。

MEANINGS.POS_TIP: A word (other than a pronoun) used to identify any of a class of people, places, or things (common noun), or to name a particular one of these (proper noun).
MEANINGS.DEF_EN: Someone who lives alone and avoids other people, often by choice.
MEANINGS.DEF_ZH: 不合群者；离群索居的人（常指自愿避开社交的人）
MEANINGS.SENT_EN: After his retirement, he became something of a hermit, rarely leaving his house.
MEANINGS.SENT_ZH: 退休后，他变得有点像个隐士，很少出门。

REGISTER: Generally formal or literary when referring to the religious sense, but common in everyday speech for the general sense of someone who keeps to themselves.
